Review title: Would I have hated it less had I not seen the original?
Review_body: The French writer/director Francis Veber is one of my favorite filmmakers...with exceptional films like "The Valet", "The Closet" and "The Dinner Game" (among others) to his credit. It's not surprising that Hollywood would want to remake one of his wonderful movies and cash in on his success. Too bad that they didn't trust Veber's wonderful script and changed it so much...dumbing it down in order, they assumed, to get a wider audience to enjoy the story.The basic movies are the same...but they are so very different as well. They both featuring a selfish man inviting who he perceives as a total idiot to a dinner party where all the sophisticated folks dig up the most annoying and stupid folks they can so they can laugh at them. The objects of their laughter THINK they're going to a nice party but there's really nothing nice about the folks running this godawful game. But so much is different beyond that....not just in the storyline but also in the way folks are portrayed. Veber's direction was generally very subtle...and nothing about this American version is subtle and it often chooses the low road instead....ruining, in my opinion, the story. Now I should point out that although the film occasionally irritated me and overall was a bust, my brother-in-law and sister-in-law loved the movie and laughed at many of the parts I hated most. I am NOT saying they are wrong or stupid....but they didn't see the French film and I wonder how much they would have enjoyed "Dinner for Schmucks" had they seen it as well. Overall, a huge misfire...and I hope people realize that the original is wonderful and clever.

Review title: A real dog's dinner of a comedy
Review_body: Now don't get me wrong I do like comedy, when it is funny and well-performed it is great. Dinner for Schmucks is not for me the worst comedy ever made or the worst movie ever made, but in my honest opinion it is among the worst of 2010 along with Fred:The Movie, The Other Guys, The Last Airbender and Vampires Suck.Seeing at how good the cast is on paper, Steve Carrell and Paul Rudd are very good with fun material, I really wanted to like Dinner for Schmucks. But there are several reasons why I couldn't even enjoy it. The film does have some decent settings and location work, but I do think the editing could have been a lot tighter, some of it seemed rather rushed.The soundtrack was lacking for me as well. I love a good soundtrack in movies, but the background scoring felt generic for me and the song choices didn't completely fit the film's mood. The direction is poor as well, when it comes to the cinematography it has some odd angles and overall direction wise it felt like too much time was spent on making the leads funny, without succeeding, rather than focusing on a decent story and script.What really brought Dinner for Schmucks down was the story and script. The story is incredibly predictable, with a number of unrealistic and poorly thought out ideas. Also it is poorly paced, I found the first act rather rushed and then as the jokes got stupider the film ground to a halt. The writing is even worse, Dinner for Schmucks has in my view a terrible script that verges more on offensive than funny while the jokes are stupid and some were delivered so fast they went over my head. I didn't like the film's tone either, it went overboard with the craziness and chaos.The acting fares little better. Carrell is talented, and when his material is good he is good too. However his material is pretty much pathetic, so in a valiant attempt to elevate the material Carrell overdoes it and it doesn't help that his character is incredibly annoying. Rudd is the opposite for me, he can be good too, but here he seems bored and underplays his part badly. It is sad as well that the chemistry between the two isn't there either.Overall, a dog's dinner of a comedy. The only redeeming quality really was the mouse art work which was quite enjoyable. 1/10 Bethany Cox

Review title: He Kind Of Grows On You
Review_body: One of the funnier episodes of Married With Children had Kelly Bundy invited to a party for dullards that was throne by the members of a MENSA group. Bud clues her in and they take some action with the other invited dullard guests.That was played strictly for laughs, but Dinner For Schmucks takes the same premise and brings a lot of pathos into the same situation. Steve Carrell plays the invited guest by Paul Rudd to a similar type party being hosted by Rudd's boss Bruce Greenwood. These Yuppies idea of entertainment is for the guests to bring along one oddball character so that they all can be laughed at and the biggest oddball winning some kind of distinction. Like Quasimodo being crowned the King of Fools.Rudd literally runs into Carrell with his car in their meeting, but he remembers the party and cultivates him for a brief spell. Although this is supposed to be of short duration and Carrell drives Rudd out of his mind, he does kind of grow on you.Carrell is funny, but like a lot of comedians of the past like Jerry Lewis, Lou Costello, and even Charlie Chaplin he brings a great deal of pathos into his role. You might even find yourself shedding a tear or two at this gentle, but completely pathetic individual.Among other things Carrell wrecks Rudd's love life with girlfriend, Stephanie Szostak. She's fine in her role, but Lucy Punch as the mad dominatrix who Rudd had a fling with is next to Carrell this best in the film.Dinner For Schmucks is a fine comedy showing off Steve Carrell's talents to full advantage. Catch it while it is still in theaters.

Review title: Fun duo but premise is just a movie excuse
Review_body: A lowly 6th floor analyst Tim (Paul Rudd) is invited to a Dinner for Idiots with the boss where everybody has to invite an idiot. He almost refuses when he runs over weirdo Barry (Steve Carell).The premise is really stupid and gets in the way of this funny duo. Paul Rudd and Steve Carell have great chemistry as a really odd couple. I wish they figure out a better way to get these two together. Carell is having a hilarious time especially with crazy Darla (Lucy Punch). Zach Galifianakis is doing another wacky character but isn't quite as successful. He and Carell do this weird thing. It's more sad than funny. This has many uneven moments, but I do love all the mice in the picture boxes.

Review title: And the Idiot does not Know Who Santos Dumont Was....
Review_body: The 1998 French comedy "Le Diner de Cons" is one of the funniest comedies I have ever seen. The witty theatrical screenplay is intelligent and hilarious and I laughed a lot along the 80 minutes running time.Unfortunately I have decided to see this American remake expecting a funny comedy but the plot is so ridiculous that I did not laugh. The title of this movie should be "A Film for Schmucks", and the screenplay writers David Guion and Michael Handelman should have wined the competition in the dinner for schmucks if they were guests for destroying the magnificent storyline. The clumsy character of Steve Carell is extremely annoying, stupid, irritating and never funny and there is no explanation why the clever Tim stays with him after the initial mess with Julie. The poor idiot does not know who Santos Dumont was in his presentation, but what else could I expect from this lame story. The good point is the sweet and beautiful Stephanie Szostak, an unknown actress that shines in this terrible flick. My vote is three.Title (Brazil): "Um Jantar Para Idiotas" ("A Dinner for Idiots")

The movie concept was great. In fact the dinner with the schmucks was very funny, I just wish there had been more of it. Rather than concentrate on what the title of the film would have us believe the movie is about, it takes its time to get there. The movie is about the relationship of Paul Rudd and various people including his gf, ex-gf and Steve Carell, the schmuck he has selected to take to a dinner filled with schmucks. This is a monthly event hosted by his boss.Steve, our schmuck, uses dead mice to make menageries of his life and the history of mankind. He is really a nice guy, who through his stupidity messes up the life of Paul Rudd. The movie makers decided the movie needed a heart warming message that schmucks have feelings too, not thinking that the audience doesn't really care. I think making Paul Rudd attend multiple parties, building up to this one would have been better than the trek these writers took.The movie was funny when it wasn't overly stupid. The reason why we laughed at those Pink Panther movies because there was a sense of possibility in all that stupidity. When you cross that line to no possibility, as this movie sometimes does, it becomes just stupid.Listen carefully to Steve Carell's lines as he mixes up words. "After sex you curl up and assume a fecal position." Funny without fart jokes. While the humor is adult, I wouldn't classify it as overly crude.

This never should have worked. The premise is evil and why would you root for someone who does something like that? Maybe because Paul Rudd is playing that person that goes wrong and he's so lovable you can't be mad at him. Not to mention that he is put through a lot during the running time of the movie.Actually so much, that you might wonder, why he doesn't stop some things from happening or just reacts another way. But again, it's a slippery slope and it could go any way. The movie does stay on the right side of evil fun most of the time. So it does succeed, which doesn't mean you will automatically like it, of course. Steve Carell is the other guy who makes this happen. If you didn't know Steve from any previous movies, you might think he is that guy he's playing. He's that good at portraying him

From director Jay Roach (Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery, Meet the Parents), apart from Three Men and a Baby and The Departed, I can't think of many remakes of foreign films that have been made better than the original, and this was another one that wasn't. Basically mid-level financial executive Tim Conrad (Paul Rudd) is successful in his job, and he is pretty sure he has a promotion in the bag, especially with his boss Lance Fender (Bruce Greenwood) inviting to the "dinner for winners". He finds out that this dinner has a catch, it is more a "dinner for idiots" because he is supposed to bring the most stupid person he can find for the after dinner entertainment, i.e. mocking. The next day he bumps into IRS employee Barry Speck (Steve Carell), with his weird personality, a strange hobby for taxidermy, particularly taking dead mice and turning them into art pieces, or "miceterpieces", Tim decides he is the perfect idiot. Soon enough he starts regretting his decision to invite Barry to dinner as he is stalking him, and staying near him causing chaos in his personal life, including mistaking one-night stand from years ago Darla (Lucy Punch) for fiancée Julie (Stephanie Szostak). Tim has the chance to make a good business associate in his boss's colleague, wealthy Swiss businessman Martin Mueller (Little Britain's David Walliams) at lunch, but of course with the Darla-Julie mix-up, this is ruined. After an encounter with Barry's rival, his boss Therman (The Hangover's Zach Galifianakis) with his "mind control" powers and who stole his wife, and a bit more chaos, Tim does come clean to his "friend" about the whole reason for the dinner. After Barry wins the idiot competition, a big disaster occurs, causing Tim's boss to fire him, and Julie loses her job too, but everything turns out well in the end. Also starring Jemaine Clement as Kieran Vollard, Jeff Dunham as Lewis the Ventriloquist, Ron Livingston as Caldwell and The IT Crowd's Chris O'Dowd as Marco the Blind Swordsman. Rudd seems like he isn't having much fun, just like Sandra Bullock in All About Steve, Carell with his glasses and brushed hair is too freaky and psychopathic to be taken light-heartedly or laugh at, I admit I did like the mouse artwork, but apart from that, this is an appalling and unfunny dog's dinner of a comedy film. Poor!

Review title: This movie will stay with you for a long time...
Review_body: I found "Dinner For Schmucks" to be quite enjoyable. Why, you ask? Well, the story was quite catching and good, it is the kind of story that grows on you and stays with you for a long time. You have the corporate man wanting to climb the rank ladder (played by Paul Rudd) and the innocent, ignorant ordinary man (played by Steve Carell), coming together and two complete opposite worlds collide.Paul Rudd was quite good in the role of Tim, playing the rules dealt by the corporate ladder, rules that doesn't really sit well with his person, but it takes the interference with someone from another world to make him come to terms with this. And Steve Carell was so amazingly cast for the lovable role as the somewhat slow and gullible Barry who sees the world differently that most others do.But the supporting cast was quite impressive as well, with names like Zach Galifianakis, Bruce Greenwood, and Ron Livingston on the list as well.I loved the way that the movie told the story, and it was really such a great story. I think lots of people could actually see parts of themselves in the Tim character, and I bet most people do not want to admit to having something of Barry to their personality. But those who fully admit to whom they are and are proud of whom they are, are the ones truly happy. And the story told in "Dinner For Schmucks" really paints this in a good way.And the whole thing that Barry had going on with the mice, wow. That was beautiful on many levels, especially when you find out why this is his hobby.Honestly, I was really surprised at how much this movie entertained me. It had comedy in good amounts, and I especially loved the brunch scene, I was laughing so hard at that point. And the movie also deals with love and romantic screw-ups in a very good way, and it comes out on the screen so well.This is a movie well worth sitting down to watch, be it by yourself, with your friends, with family, or with a loved one. There is something for everyone in this movie. And anyone who will not find the story touching in even the slightest way, should perhaps take some things in his or her life up to re-evaluation. This movie took me by storm, let it do the same to you.

Sometimes, even in comedy, you need to have people that you can sort of, kind of, care about. Even if things get exaggerated, or surreal, the audience shouldn't be looking at their watches or sitting uncomfortably as the obnoxious and strange-for-its-own-sake goes across the screen. Dinner for Schmucks takes off from a French film by Frances Veber, The Dinner Game (which I saw a decade ago and only remember I enjoyed, though not enough to see more than the once in 1999), and has been updated mostly for the sake of giving some more room for locations- originally the Veber film was like a play, set in the guy's house for the dinner- and with lots of comedy actors and so on. It's also helmed by Jay Roach, which is a decent sign of things to come but never a great one (not since the first Austin Powers at least, and that was for Mike Myers comeback).It's the story of the bourgeoisie and the lower-class idiots of the world; watching the film I got the sense it was like a distant, younger relative of Luis Bunuel's style of comedy in attacking the disgusting rich and giving some absurdist praise for the lower rungs of society (think Exterminating Angel with the climax of Viridiana for you fans out there). But it lacks the kind of focus and savage wit that Bunuel had. It's kind of a soft upper-middle class saga of a man, Tim, is after a job on the "7th floor" with the other big-wigs, but has to participate in a 'dinner' where everyone brings a 'fool' to make fun of. Enter in a sudden moment of chance (by head-on collision) Barry, a weird little man who works as an IRS analyst by day and makes dioramas of mice by night.Tim has his chance, but what about his girlfriend who is disgusted with the idea and is thinking about leaving him because of it? It's around this point, when Barry shows up again at Tim's place and doesn't leave for nearly the twenty-four hours until the dinner, that the film starts to lose its comedic footing. Early on we meet a supporting character, a creepy but amusingly over-the-top "arteest" played by Jemaine Clement, who puts himself really into the work and dons horns and other apparel in his artwork, often with hot-ass girls. He's funny, if a predictable character, and one hopes the film can at least continue in this context. But what comes across at first as a kind of sweet-natured annoyance from Carrel's character just turns to... annoyance, with the occasional mice diorama.The dioramas, in fact, steal the show. They also open the film in a striking credits sequence of various mice set up in designs and clothes and backdrops to the Beatles "Fool on the Hill". It's a beautiful, absurd little number, and it barely reaches that authentic whimsy and fun again. Scene after scene, Barry keeps poking his head in Tim's business, or his business affairs (i.e. trying to sweet-talk a Swiss man to go with the money firm or whatever), and while the point is mostly clear- that annoying idiots still have hearts to and can be endearing- it's muddled by a) it not often being funny, and compounded in unfunny stature with the appearance of a stalker-of-Tim's who is even WORSE than Barry, and b) a lack of focus as the plot continues to its inevitable climax. Even supporting players that *should* be dynamite like Zach Galifinakis fall flat under the strain of over-awkward comedy.As I mentioned, Bunuel could have done wonders with this sort of material. It mixes social satire and the genuine bizarre people of the world together, and it should be funnier. Should being the operating word; sometimes it IS quite funny, mostly due to Clement or the occasional aside from Rudd or Carrel. But the climax is overstuffed with predictability and snide commentary. Somehow director Roach sees a lot of this as believable in its situation to situation, but it isn't. Why would Tim go so far with this guy? There's an underlying nastiness to the movie too, and it's sometimes hard to pinpoint until one sees it, and it's in the guise of a sweet-but-bizarre comedy of manners. Again, the mice- especially mouse Vincent Van Gogh and Ben Franklin- steal the show. I would just turn it on for those scenes, or maybe some of Clement's scene-stealers. It's mostly a disappointment of tone and obnoxious tendencies.

Review title: Steve Carell and Paul Rudd make another good teaming in Dinner for Schmucks
Review_body: Okay, Dinner for Schmucks is a comedy with overtones of schmaltz, slapstick, and silliness that somehow is mostly very enjoyable in spite of itself. Certainly the reteaming of straight man Paul Rudd and eccentric Steve Carell makes the whole thing go down pretty easy even during the more cringeworthy parts. And they're surrounded by some other wonderfully crazy characters like Zach Galifianakis as an I.R.S. man who's sleeping with Carell's ex-wife, Jemaine Clement as an artist named Kieran, or Lucy Punch as Rudd's stalker Darla. Throw in Bruce Greenwood as Rudd's boss, David Walliams as potential client Fender Mueller, and Stephanie Szostak as Rudd's potential fiancée Julie and the whole thing has enough humor and heart to make this one of the most enjoyable comedies this season. Director Jay Roach of the Austin Powers and the Focker comedies lets things get a little wild before settling to a more sentimental climax that doesn't get too cloying. Certainly the use of The Beatles' "The Fool on the Hill" contributes to the feel-good vibe felt throughout...

What genius in Hollywood thought he could improve on an original French film that stands by itself, which in addition, was witty and funny? Judging by other 'adaptations' for movies that originated in France, the odds for 'Dinner for Schmucks' to succeed as a good comedy were nil, at best. This was a project that might have appeared to being ripe for the trans Atlantic voyage, but alas, something happened before it landed in L.A.This was obviously a Steve Carell's vehicle. After all, he was going to play the schmuck in the film. From all his films, we thought this must have been his worst appearance. Mr. Carell has done much better, something that unfortunately does not happen under the direction of Jay Roach, a man identified with the Fockers and Austin Powers sagas. The problem seems to be the screenplay written by David Guion and Michael Handelman. It is over plotted and over long. In comparison, the original "Le diner de cons", created by Francis Veber looks like a masterpiece.The best thing in the film is Paul Rudd, playing the straight man, to Mr. Carell's goofy, mice loving guy. Mr. Rudd is an impeccable actor who always manages to shine in whatever he is asked to play. The side story of Kieran, as played by Jemaine Clement and the IRS inspector of Zach Galifianakis, just do not make it because both characters are phonies. Lucy Punch has some good moments as the woman infatuated with Tim. Kristen Schaal casts a nice presence as well as the beautiful Stephanie Szostak, who plays Julie. Bruce Greenwood, a serious actor, had the misfortune to play the mean boss giving the party for the 'schmucks'.

"Austin Powers" director Jay Roach serves up a less than appetizing rehash of French director Francis Veber's 1998 comic masterpiece "The Dinner Game." "Dinner for Schmucks" casts Paul Rudd cast as the straight man, while Steve Carell hams it up as a dim-witted idiot. Rudd and Carell have now co-starred in three comedies. Previously, they appeared together in "The 40-Year-Old Virgin" and "Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy." No, "Dinner for Schmucks" isn't half as hilarious as either "40-Year-Old Virgin" or "Anchorman." The premise of this half-baked hokum is that our hero's arrogant boss throws a once-a-month dinner party where his best and brightest employees compete to see who can bring the dumbest dinner guest. Typically, the dinner guests are such incredible imbeciles that they don't realize that they are being roasted instead of toasted. Essentially, these cold-blooded bigwigs at a private equity firm that cuts up other firms and sells off their assets need something for a good laugh. Unfortunately, "Dinner for Schmucks" comes up short on yucks. This politically incorrect plate of pabulum concerns an ambitious, young analyst who is prepared to sell his soul to the Philistines so he can realize his dreams, specifically marrying his girlfriend. Along the way, our hero realizes the error of ridiculing idiots so that he can attain his dreams. Long before he grasps what he has done, the humor in "Dinner for Schmucks" has lost its seasoning. The original French comedy concluded before the eponymous dinner. "Dinner for Schmucks," however, goes in for a seven course meal and wears out its welcome. Mind you, it is always a pleasure to watch Carell cutting up, and he seems to be genuinely having fun as an IRS processor and mouse taxidermist who assembles the dead rodents in detailed dioramas. Incidentally, designer Joel Venti and the cult effects Chiodo brothers, Charles, Edward and Stephen , who fashioned the puppets for "Team America: World Police," whipped up these inventive dioramas. The point is that Carell steals the show, but the show really isn't worth stealing. When Carell isn't carrying on his shtick, "Dinner for Schmucks" sucks.Financial analyst Tim (Paul Rudd of "Sidekicks") has been pestering his cute girlfriend Julie (Stephanie Szostak of "The Devil Wears Prada") to marry him, but she is a career girl who orchestrates elaborate art deals. Meanwhile, Tim lives in an elegant apartment and drives an expensive sports car that he really cannot afford. After the president of Tim's firm, Lance Fender (Bruce Greenwood of "Star Trek"), pink-slips an executive who took the business down the wrong path, Tim angles for the promotion. Tim concocts a scheme to bring a fabulously wealthy Swiss entrepreneur, Mueller (David Walliams of "Stardust"), to Fender Finances. Mueller owns a munitions firm with tons of leftover ordinance from World War I, basically bombs, and Tim has figured out a way to convert the bombs into lamps. Of course, Fender Finances will take a bath marketing the bomb lamps, but they will clean up managing Mueller's portfolio. Fender is desperately looking for ideas to turn his company around when Tim pitches his proposal. Initially, Fender wants to hand the project over to one of his surefire executives, but he finds Tim's blind ambition so refreshing that he lets him woo Mueller. Fender tells our hero about his super-secret party and invites him to bring the biggest boob. It doesn't take Julie long to convince Tim that the dinner is a dumb idea. Nevertheless, Tim needs that promotion so desperately so he can sweep Julie off her feet that he sets out to find a loser.Literally, Tim runs into a loser. Barry (Steve Carell) is picking up a dead mouse for his mice diorama when Tim hits him. Fortunately, Barry is none the worse for landing on Tim's hood and then being hurled several feet away. Initially, Tim fears the worst when Barry and he try to reach a monetary agreement, until Tim realizes that Barry plans to pay him for the damage to his sports car. After Tim breathes a sigh of relief, he asks Barry what he was doing in the middle of the street. Barry shows Tim a dead mouse that he was trying to retrieve from the street before our hero could flatten it with his care. Barry flaunts a book that contains photographs of the dead mice after he has dressed them up to resemble famous paintings, such as Whistler's mother. Tim knows a good thing when he sees it and cultivates Barry's friendship. Meantime, after Julie gets wind of what Tim plans to do, she wants to break up and devote herself to her latest insane art client, Kieran (Jemaine Clement of "Gentlemen Broncos"), whose art works of himself dressed up in a satyr costume are selling like crazy. As nutty as Barry is, Barry stands no chance alongside the warped, egotistical genius of Kieran. Predictably, Tim learns his lesson, and Barry and he show up Fender for the snobbish ape that he really is. However, before Barry can win the trophy as the biggest idiot, he must confront his intimidating IRS co-worker, Therman (Zach Galifianakis of "The Hangover"), another hopeless moron who constantly overshadows Barry.Incongruity is the source of the best comedy. The buffoons that Steve Carell, Jemaine Clement, and Zach Galifianakis play in "Dinner for Schmucks" are as funny as this labored comedy gets. What makes these performances work so well is that the actors appear to have no idea how ridiculous they look. Carell looks like he is channeling the comic actor Austin Pendleton of "My Cousin Vinny" with his spectacles, buck-teeth, and wacky haircut that makes him look particularly nerdy. Jemaine Clement scores points for "Dinner" as an eccentric artist obsessed with all things goat, and Zach Galifianakis never misses a chance to make himself look hopelessly cretinous. Despite its interesting characters, "Dinner for Schmucks" belongs in a richly deserved doggie bag, but not as a treat.

Review title: Comedic blend of Apatow heart/Farrelly Bros' instincts & LaBute underpinings; hysterically funny - Rudd & Carell make an inspired odd couple
Review_body: DINNER FOR SCHMUCKS (2010) ***1/2 Steve Carell, Paul Rudd, Zach Galifianakis, Jemaine Clement, Stephanie Szotstak, Lucy Punch, Bruce Greenwood, David Walliams, Ron Livingston, Larry Wilmore, Kristen Schaal, PJ Byrne, Andrea Savage, Lucy Davenport, Chris O'Dowd, Jeff Dunham, Octavia Spencer, Rick Overton, Patrick Fischler. Hysterically funny high concept comedy – loosely based on the popular French farce "Le Diner de Cons" – with nice guy corporate ladder climber Rudd finding himself invited to the titular soiree – which involves the invitee to bring along the most ridiculous loser they can find to humiliate (enter doofus Carell having a field day and milking some pathos with the pathetic). What comes across as a hyper blend of Apatow heartwarming gross out comedy with Farrelly Brothers' instincts and an undercoating of bilious Neil LaBute, the film runs on all comedy cylinders with no holds-barred with some truly hilarious bits (namely Rudd attempting to coerce his fiancée Szotstak away from pompous ass 'artist' Clement who nearly steals the movie) and a few genuine sequences of emotional breakdowns (namely Carell's nemesis IRS colleague Galifianakis and his 'hypnotic mind puppetery'!) Love the meticulous 'mousterpieces' that Carell turns into art (dioramas of taxidermied mice!) (Dir: Jay Roach)

Greetings again from the darkness. I fully expected this to be an all-out raunch-com in the vein of "The Hangover", and I was absolutely mistaken. The film only slips into slapstick and physical punchlines at the lowest part of the actual dinner. The rest of the movie is pretty basic and set near real life.Often, real life situations bring the most humor. Sadly, that's not the case here. Most of this one is just plain boring. There are some very talented people associated with this one and they all do a fine job. It's just that the pieces don't make up a whole. The film basically rides on the shoulders of the talented Steve Carell as Barry. Barry is a genuinely nice guy whose wife left him for his boss (Zach Galfianakis), and his hobby is making intricate displays of dressed up dead mice ... his "mouseterpieces", he calls them.Paul Rudd plays Tim, another genuinely nice trying very hard to make it in the business world. He has the right car and a great apartment and a beautiful girlfriend (Stephanie Szostack) who doesn't think it's time for them to be married. Tim seizes an opportunity at work to go for a promotion. This gets him invited to his boss's monthly dinner party where all the managers bring a guest with extraordinary skills ... the schmucks of the title. The point is to have a good laugh at the expense of the idiots. Obviously Tim runs into Barry and guest list is complete.Tim explains to his girlfriend that there is a "me you don't know" who has to do things in order to get ahead at work. I really wanted to see more of THAT guy! Instead, we are subjected to another film that just doesn't know how to take advantage of Paul Rudd's talent. He is a funny guy and you would never know it here.If not for Steve Carell and an outlandish performance by Jemaine Clement (Flight of the Conchords) as an "artist", this film would be totally flat. Instead, there are a few laughs and an underlying theme about the sweetness of some people. It tries to ask the question, who are the real schmucks? Director Jay Roach is responsible for the Austin Powers and the Meet the Parents franchises. He obviously knows humor. He takes this one from a French film directed by Francis Veber called "The Dinner Game". In that film, we never actually get to the dinner. In this one, the film sinks to its lowest point during the dinner. Lesson learned. Best part? Hearing the Beatles during the opening and closing credits.

Dinner for Schmucks (2010): Dir: Jay Roach / Cast: Steve Carell, Paul Rudd, Jemaine Clement, Zach Galifianakis, Lucy Punch: Hilarious comedy not so much about idiots, but about those making such accusations. Paul Rudd wishes to move ahead in his job but first he must attend an annual dinner where he must bring an idiot for the amusement of the guests. He encounters Steve Carell who dresses up dead mice for scenery pieces. One of director Jay Roach's best and funniest. He previously introduced the world to the antics of Austin Powers. Carell is a hoot as the unpredictable nerd who lives to laugh but often causes havoc. Part of this is in no due part to his e-mail response on Rudd's computer to an intimidating ex-girlfriend. What Carell teaches us here is done in form by accepting who he is and whom others believe he is and running with it because in the end, he is the one who laughs loudest. Rudd is very good and a terrific foil to Carell's antics but his concluding decision is obvious. Among unique supporting players is Jemaine Clement, an exhibitionist laying claim to Rudd's girlfriend, and Zach Galifianakis as a corrupt hypnotist who will meet his match in a very strange way at the dinner. Lucy Punch is funny in a brief but pivotal scene as Rudd's stalking ex-girlfriend whom Carell makes contact with, resulting in brawl. This dinner is complete with a variety of strange looking characters that are suppose to be the brunt of a joke but we are left admiring their creative get-ups and egos. Very creative and unique comedy about judging others, and other such appetizers. Score: 9 / 10

Review title: Funny at Times! Faithful to the Original French Version to some degree!
Review_body: Steve Carell really shows his comedic range in this film. You can't help but like Barry, the IRS taxidermist, who was hit by Tim's car as he was collecting a dead mouse off the street in Los Angeles. Tim is played brilliantly by Paul Rudd. Tim is a businessman who wants to get promoted and hopefully engaged to Julie, his live-in girlfriend who is an art museum curator. At the moment, she is representing Kieran Vollard who has some pretty weird taste in his artistic endeavors. Anyway, Tim meets Barry and his life changes for the worse or the better depending upon how you look at it. Both men have more in common than they realize. Barry's wife leaves him for his boss, Thurman, who becomes a guest at the infamous dinner for idiots. While Barry thinks the other guests are remarkable, Tim knows the real reason that they're all there. I like this film and I think the director didn't go too far into the ridiculous as he could have done. In fact, the film has a lot less vulgarity in language and even sexual relations although there is some sexuality especially with Kieran. I expected sick jokes at times but I found the humor to be mild and tame and they told the story of an unusual friendship. The original French version ended differently but I wanted Tim to make the same revelation that he's the biggest idiot and maybe we all are. It's funny how two different people like Tim and Barry can become friends who did need each other and learned from each other.

Review title: A Nutshell Review: Dinner for Schmucks
Review_body: Based upon the film Le Diner de Cons, Dinner for Schmucks is the Hollywood remake directed by Jay Roach, who is better known for being at the helm of films such as the Austin Powers trilogy, and Meet the Parents/Fockers, all of which are some of my favourite comedies. Dinner for Schmucks however isn't that laugh a minute forgettable flick, but rather is a more sombre tale to remind us of the little guy that's always around, easy to tread on and bullied by the high and mighty.Paul Rudd stars as Tim, an analyst who is dreaming of moving upwards in his company's corporate ladder. He gets the attention of CEO Lance Fender (Bruce Greenwood) through a rather brash stand out moment during a meeting, and is given that 5 minute elevator pitch to join the firm's head honchos in a dinner where he would be welcomed into the fold if he can meet their expectations - that is to bring along an idiot as his dinner guest, and they were all to laugh at him. The objective is secret of course, and everyone will bring someone in a competition of sorts. It's unorthodox and reeks of elitism, but desperate to get that cushy job, he goes against the wishes of his girlfriend Julie (Stephanie Szostak) and fate allows him to bump into Barry (Steve Carell), a simpleton taxidermist who works on mice.As you can predict, much of the comedy comes at the expense of Barry, who speaks funny, behaves oddly, and most of the time you wonder if you're guilty of the same if you were to laugh at him and his antics. It's evil that we get to laugh at someone who's most unfortunate and naive, but that's how David Guion and Michael Handelman's story sets it out to be, with Barry being the fall guy at the receiving end of the butt of the jokes, while Tim slowly undergoes a painful lesson the ill intentions go through a karmic circle as we see his life turn upside down where misfortunes become lucky escapes which in turn sets itself up for a bigger fall.Steve Carell is a great comedian, and like his Maxwell Smart in Get Smart, his Barry here is loony with a capital L, who lives life in his own cocoon which I suspect had snapped when his wife cheated on him with his boss Therman (Zach Galifianakis), who claims to possess the power to read minds since he works in the tax bureau and can see through guys hiding something. The major scene played in the office is nothing but insane and frankly, idiotic, but sets itself up nicely for the big mano a mano in the last act, which unfortunately came across as a little stretched. Thanks to Carell's presence, he brings to life a comedy of disastrous situations though it's still a little bit unnerving to consciously know you're laughing at someone's misfortune.With the strong underlying message of what friendship means and how we learn to accept the drawbacks of our friends, Paul Rudd stars in his second bromance after I Love You Man to explore just that, but it's Jemaine Clement (from Flight of the Conchords) who steals the show as Kieran the artist who's so full of himself and pretentious. Now that is something I can wholeheartedly laugh at!

Review title: A Comedy Afriad of It's Own Shadow
Review_body: The 2010 year, the start of a new decade, has not delivered too many laugh out loud, hilarious Comedies, at least none that I've seen. The only Comedy I think I've liked this year is She's Out of My League honestly. This movie had a good cast of people, cameos and leads. Still, from the trailers and the reception, I had full expectations that this would be a funny movie, not living up to The Hangover in terms of jokes, but at least an above average film. What I got was a mix of some good laughs, some flop jokes, and scenes that dragged on way too long.The plot is a hard one to explain, Tim (Rudd) is a hardworked, up-tight business man who is empowered to sell model lamps to his boss Mueller. Not to mention he has a girlfriend Julie (Szostak) who is getting a curator deal for a friend named Keiran (Clement). After being invited to a dinner when surprising everyone with the unexpected lamp surprise, Tim learns from his boss that he has to find an idiot to bring to the dinner and if the idiot is chosen as the stupidest he'll win an award and get the job. So its more of a mockery rather than a true honor. When Tim hits Barry (Carell) with his car by accident, they become closely acquainted, but since Barry jabbers on and on and basically makes an idiot out of himself while simultaneously ruining Tim's life, he believes that he can use Barry in the dinner and hopefully get his lamps selling. Barry also has an obsession with dead mice, making them into nic-nacs after cleaning them up and practically having a whole mice world in his basement.The Comedy is slow for the first half of the movie, but picks up real fast once Barry is introduced. I can say a lot much about this movie, for instance, we all have the "Barry" character in our lives. Someone who is too nice and someone who tries to help out while at the same time destroying your life. Schmucks also has jokes that are sometimes laugh out loud ones, sometimes they fall very flap, and some small grins. This movie is almost afraid to go to far which is to blame because of the PG-13 rating. If this had an R rating we could have gotten more out of the characters. A possible vulgar outburst from Barry, a very loud fight with Julie and Tim, a lot of scenes could have been added to make this film funnier if it wasn't cut back to PG-13. Also, its noticeable that the jokes are recycled, but used as if they are fresher than when they were first used. But jokes that are as if they are new come very rarely.It also includes one of my favorite songs for a brief eight seconds. You guessed it's "Escape (The Pina Colada Song)" by Rupert Holmes. It was used in Grown Ups as well and The Sweetest Thing. It made me smile when I heard it and I believe it gave a more open mind about what to expect.The movie also tends to drag on way too long. This movie is fit for a ninety minute runtime. No need to exaggerate the plot to 114 minutes. Most scenes featuring Rudd/Carell go on a while since the character Barry needs seem like a slow-witted person. The whole movie focuses on a dinner that doesn't happen until the very end. It should have just been called Meet the Schmucks or just plain Schmucks. Or if you want to be real corny, Whatta Buncha Schmucks! fits well.The movie all in all isn't new, but it acts as if it is. There are cool scenes of the mice dioramas made by Barry which is probably one of the top qualities about this film. The pros revolve around Rudd/Carell being great together, some huge laughs, a fine overall plot, Jeff Dunham's cameo is excellent and unexpected as well as the return of Office Space star, Ron Livingston, whos cameo is great too, and semi-believable characters. The cons are its overly long, Barry's approach is tedious at times, the plots recycled, Zach Galifianakis's cameo is too dumb to believe, and a trimmed rating. Its good in my book, but it could be better.Starring: Steve Carell, Paul Rudd, Zach Galifianakis, Jemaine Clement, Jeff Dunham, Bruce Greenwood, Ron Livingston, and Kristen Schaal. Directed by: Jay Roach.

Review title: An insult to creative outcasts and individuals everywhere!
Review_body: 'DINNER FOR SCHMUCKS': Two and a Half Stars (Out of Five) Jay Roach, director of both the 'MEET THE PARENTS' and 'AUSTIN POWERS' franchises, directs this remake of the French 1998 film 'THE DINNER GAME'. It's co-scripted by David Guion and Michael Handelman (who also wrote 'THE EX') and stars Steve Carell and Paul Rudd (who apparently can only co-star in buddy films). It's also highlighted by memorable co-starring performances from Zach Galifianakis, Ron Livingston, Bruce Greenwood and Stephanie Szostak (who bares a striking resemblance to a younger Julia Ormond and is just as beautiful and talented, all though her part is a little weak and annoying here). Even with all that talent the film still flounders; all though hilarious at times it's way too ridiculous and mean spirited as well.I've never seen the original but I've gathered, from reading about it, that this is a somewhat loose remake. It revolves around Tim (Rudd) an exec desperately looking for advancement at his business in order to impress his girlfriend (Szostak) who he continually asks to marry him, and even carries around a ring for. When given the chance of a promotion, through the firing of another employee, Tim jumps at the chance to impress his bosses. He learns that this includes attending a dinner in which employees pride themselves in bringing the biggest idiot they can find, to mock and make fun of for the enjoyment of others. His conscious and his girlfriend are dead set against this but when he meets Barry (Carell) he can't resist the opportunity. Barry is a sweet heart-ed but naive and sheltered buffoon who prides himself by making art displays out of dead mice, which he uses his taxidermy skills on. The movie pretty much writes itself from there.Parts of the movie are laugh out loud hilarious thanks to impressive performances, writing and directing but other parts are appalling thanks to performances, writing and directing. The concept itself is brilliant, which I'm guessing the original film is as well, but this remake is way too over the top and unbelievable as well as just ugly and mean spirited. It pretends to be in good will and have a small heart at times but really it's an insult to creative outcasts and individuals everywhere. The 'loveable losers' presented in this movie are shown as annoying and idiotic pests on normal citizens who we should love because they mean well. It's really patronizing and insulting to anyone who dares to step outside of the norm, although it briefly pretends to be otherwise. The movie is not realistic in any way and does make several jokes at the expense of others, just like the majority of it's characters. Movies like 'THE 40 YEAR OLD VIRGIN', 'PLANES, TRAINS & AUTOMOBILES' and the more recent 'SHE'S OUT OF MY LEAGUE' represent a more heartfelt and sincere example of similar subject matter. The movie is really funny at times but it really leaves a bad taste in your mouth after-wards. Some people, like many of the characters and film makers of this movie, think it makes them look clever and smart to make fun of others but that's really easy and anyone can do it. Some of us just choose not to.Watch our review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5YDpWRaEnYQ

Review title: Only the beginning and ending of the film redeem the one-hour mess that goes in-between ...
Review_body: I remember when I heard that "The Dinner Game", one of the greatest French comedies ever written, was going to be remade in America, my initial reaction was "Not again!" or "Haven't they learned the lesson?" Of all the Francis Veber's movies that got the remake-treatment, none inspired a remake worthy of comparison, and the remakes immediately sunk into oblivion. Who remembers now "The Man with One Red Shoe", "Pure Luck" or "Father's Day"? Not Jay Roach apparently, who directed "Dinner for Schmucks" with Steve Carrell playing the role of the late Jacques Villeret and Paul Rudd as the obligatory straight man.The casting was promising though, and the film deserved at least to be given the benefit of the doubt. However, my first glance at the movie poster confirmed my initial fears: Carrell looked too dumb, and I knew the Americans would get the meaning of 'cons' (the titular insult in the original comedy) totally wrong. Villeret played a 'con' as a lovable buffoon who, despite all his efforts to help and make up for his mistakes, was generating one disaster after another. He was still a 'normal' man, one you got to talk to a few minutes before realizing how idiotic he is. "Dinner for Schmucks" goes straight to the point, an idiot has to look idiot, in case people wouldn't notice a man collecting dead mouses to recreate famous paintings or historical scenes would be mentally challenged.The problem is that the initial premise of the film was deliberately cruel (a group of rich snobs inviting a fool to vote for the most idiotic one) but it made the series of incidents punctuating the narrative even more rewarding, we wanted the rich villain to get his comeuppance, as no decent person would laugh at people mocking other people. In "Dinner for Schmucks", Carrel looks crazy, stupid, in fact, he doesn't need to do anything to make you laugh, he's already a comical character. I thought there would be a thin line between French and American sophistication, it was not even a gap, it was a ravine. Therefore, we laugh at Carrell too, we laugh at his stupidity and craziness, and it's Paul Rudd we feel sorry for. The roles are reversed and it's almost painful to see Rudd going through this nightmare since he didn't even want to be involved in the dinner (contrarily to his French alter-ego who was a cocky bastard).The problem with "The Dinner Game" is to over-exploit the idiocy of the main character at a point you wonder whether he is a moron or a retarded person, and to make things worse, the characters who were supposed to behave normally in the French version, are all parodied to the worst, the mistress is a slutty and pervert nymphomaniac, the IRS colleague another idiot in a more psychic level, and don't get me started on all the other 'idiots' invited for the dinner. I wanted to feel sorry for them, but the film insists so much on their 'peculiarity' that the only feeling that clearly came to me was pity. However, it would be a lie to say that none of these character made me laugh, but while the French version's gags mostly relied on comedy-of-errors, verbal humor and confusion, "Dinner for Schmucks" contained too much slapstick and gross gags to make you focus on the more subtle parts, and to the heart of the story, which was the friendship and understanding growing between Rudd and Carrell. Yes, because despite my criticism, the film had its moments and some of them touched me."Dinner for Schmucks" had a great potential, something that could have elevated it to the same level of poignancy and tenderness than "40-Year Old Virgin", even more because Carrel's character had a sweet side, expressed through his passion. Paul Rudd played his part perfectly, even better than Lhermitte, and interestingly, the film developed the dinner's concept more than the original. The first part in the company is cleverly written and made me expect a much more mature humor, the relationship with his fiancé provided the perfect dosage of romance. But the "Dinner" was too great a concept not to be filled by visual gags, the French version focused on the interactions between the two leads, the second one knew it had to be a warmer tone, less cynical, but while the intentions were good, the means are debatable.As a result, the film both starts and ends in a very positive way, and the mess that goes in-between is only redeemed by the whole tenderness still inhabiting the story. I confess that some gags really made me laugh, a psychological struggle with the telephone and the reaction of Carrel made me burst out laughter, but one or two gags perfectly delivered is still better than a series of gags begging for laughs. From the Gothic animal-lover artist, to the women who talked to dead animals, the movie plunged us in an ocean of absurdity and surrealism that killed off all the charm.I ended the French film's review by this sentence "just because someone looks and sounds like a fool doesn't mean he's not one", and this was referring to the ending of the film which was a strike of genius in terms of comical writing and a perfect conclusion. In "Dinner for Schmucks" , we already know that, there isn't much left to surprise you at the end  to take you totally off-guard, as if the script wasted so much energy in its avalanche of gags, that it was already out of breath at the end, and could only distribute the obligatory conclusions we all expected. A pity because the film had a great potential.

Review title: You won't be a schmuck for renting this one, for it has its moments, but, the film does go flat, at times
Review_body: Tim (Paul Rudd) is in love with a beautiful woman, Julie (Stephanie Szostak), and its hard. She is a budding art museum curator and, although she seems to love him, she won't put the ring on her finger that Paul constantly takes out of his pocket. To help his case, Tim is trying hard to climb his investment firm's ladder and, in fact, comes up with a brilliant idea to lure a wealthy Swiss man into becoming a client. The head honcho (Bruce Greenwood) is pleased. However, to ensure that Tim has the right stuff, the bossman lets Tim know that his relevance at an upcoming dinner party will be critical. Each member of the company that attends must bring a "schmuck", a loser, to the event. The person whose guest is the "worst" will snare a trophy AND be a top dog at work. When Tim tells Julie of the dinner, she is appalled and asks that Tim not do such a despicable thing. Unfortunately, a prime candidate, Barry (Steve Carell) literally runs in front of Tim's car and falls to the ground. This IRS employee is earnest but dimwitted and makes dead mouse dioramas in his spare time. Hanging out for a day or two together, Barry messes up Tim's life in a big way. A psycho ex-girlfriend of Tim's comes calling, thanks to Barry's Internet invitation, and Julie, getting caught in the fray that follows, bolts out the door and into the arms of a client. Eventually, there is nothing for Tim to do but take Barry to the dinner. Will Tim win the competition but, more importantly, will Julie come back to him and will Barry be hurt by the dinner's raison d'etre? Based on a French film, this American translation lacks something, being very uneven. Sometimes its very funny and other times, the jokes fall flat. But, the cast is wonderful and the movie's best asset. Carell and Rudd are a great duo, like Abbott and Costello, and Zach Galifianakis, Greenwood, Szostak, Ron Livingston, and all of the others truly "make" the film a success. That said, the settings are also very fine, with Rudd's apartment absolutely stunning in its decor. Costumes, too, are well-selected and the camera work is also nice. As stated above, however, the script and direction are on again, off again, making for a wee bit of disappointment in the overall final picture. No, you will not be a schmuck if you see this one, it has some great moments. Likely it is, however, that you will suffer a small letdown as the ending credits roll.

Review title: A comedy about and "idiot" changing your life. Carell was born to play this part
Review_body: An account executive (Rudd) discovers the only way for him to get a promotion at his company is to find his own "special person" (Carell) and invite him to a company dinner. If you go off just the main 2 stars alone this is a must rent. This is one of those movies that come out where the script alone has a chance of being really funny, but it all comes down to casting. In this case the casting of every part, even the little ones, is what pushes this movie over the top into one of the funniest movies that has been released in a while. It's hard to imagine what the movie would have been like with out Rudd and Carell but I'm guessing not as good. This part seems written for Carell, he plays it perfectly and it is his funniest role since Brick in "Anchorman". The one downfall of the movie is that it is entirely predictable (most comedies are), but it is still a fun ride till the end. It seems like every comedy since the "Hangover" promotes itself as "The funniest movie since the Hangover", this one can actually live up to that standard. A definite must watch and I dare you not to laugh. I give it a B+

Dinner for SchmucksThe best thing about inviting schmucks to dinner is that you can serve them breakfast and they'll never grasp the irony.However, the dolt in this rambunctious comedy may not even possess the smarts to make it to the meal. After landing a Swiss mogul (David Walliams), the tenacious Tim (Paul Rudd) is finally recognized by the higher ups at his firm. Unfortunately that involves participating in their twisted games.When his boss (Bruce Greenwood) orders him to invite a putz to a dinner where all of the executives can mock them, Tim abides.But, by inviting an eccentric part-time taxidermist (Steve Carell) to the feast, Tim may have bitten off more than he can chew.Despite its illustrious cast, this English remake of The Dinner Game fails to dish-out even one comedic morsel.Furthermore, inviting idiots to a resplendent repast is a necessity – who's going to wash the dishes? (Red Light)

Review title: Okay comedy that probably didn't live up to its potential
Review_body: I have mixed feelings about this film. I spent much of the film unable to decide whether it was a good or bad film. In the end, I came down on the good side, but not in any resounding way. And oddly enough, through the climax of the film I was somehow reminded of Beetlejuice, although I don't know why...something about the particular sense of humor used through the films.Steve Carrel does have some good moments when he makes his character very sympathetic. Review title: Misleading trailers mixed with unfunny humour and dull predictable situations
Review_body: Dinner for Schmucks had very misleading trailers. Having not seen the original French version of the film, I didn't really know exactly what this film would be based on or how it would be. I saw many trailers showing the dinner as the main target, yet while watching the film, the whole dinner is basically just used as a subplot. It gets talked about quite a lot throughout the film but once it reaches that point, it seems very dull and predictable. The main plot was basically the relationship with Paul Rudd's character and his girlfriend after Steve Carell's character comes into Rudd's life only to stir up their relationship.Their were may awkward situations and many unfunny scenes. For most the characters were just annoying and unlikable, specifically Stev Carell's character. His character Barry just forced himself threw Tim's life without anything- he cause him to ruined Tim's relationship with his girlfriend and almost ruining his job promotion, yet of course at the end it ends with a happy ending. The dinner scene (start around 83min) was quite okay, not funny as it should have been but entertaining in the least. The mouse art by Carell's character was pretty neat. Overall though, the film was quite disappointing and I didn't laugh throughout The point of the movie is how miserable Tim's life is made by Barry, and audiences will know exactly how he feels.

Review title: Idiocy reigns supreme, for better or for worse
Review_body: The French film that "Dinner for Schmucks" draws its inspiration from,  "Le Diner de Cons," was successful because it made us seriously ponder  who the real idiot was -- the up-and- coming businessman or the dolt he  must invite to a business dinner. With "Schmucks," you seriously ponder  if the real idiot has been you for watching the thing in the first  place. Good news is if you can make it through the bumbling first half,  "Schmucks" turns itself around in almost redeeming fashion.  Paul Rudd plays Tim and Steve Carell plays Barry. The former works at  an Equity Firm and seeks a big promotion; the latter works for the IRS  and makes dioramas featuring dead mice dressed as people. Their paths  cross because after hitting Barry with his car, Tim realizes he's a  perfect fit for the "idiot dinner" that his boss has invited him to,  one that he learns will have implications for his future at the firm.  Unfortunately, Barry is a bit of a leech, and what Tim expects to be a  brief dinner that he can forget about later turns into 48 hours of  mind- numbing stupidity.  Not until Tim gets stuck deep in the shenanigans does any real humor  come out of "Schmucks." At first, writers Michael Handelman and David  Guion (co-writers of the barely seen comedy "The Ex" starring Jason  Bateman and Zach Braff) determine that Barry's idiocy justifies him  instigating the film's events with any absurd action they deem helpful  to the story. While we learn eventually just how clueless Barry really  is, his character had not been established as so socially inconsiderate  as to instant message with Tim's stalker Darla (Lucy Punch), the event  that sets everything into motion. Once that snowball gets rolling, the  situational comedy that ends up working does come out of it, but that  singular action was weakly constructed, topping the long and bad  highlight reel of the first act.  The moment that turns around "Dinner for Schmucks" completely comes at  an important business meeting between Tim and a Swiss billionaire  looking to invest with the firm. Tim's expecting a letdown because his  girlfriend, Julie (Stephanie Szostak), who was supposed to attend with  him to talk art with the investor's wife, has walked out on Tim,  partially thanks to Barry. In hopes of saving the day, Barry recruits  Darla the psycho to pose as Julie without telling Tim about it. Barry  and Darla join the meeting, which doesn't go quite how you'd expect.  Although spurred by the recurring "accidental cell phone switch" gag,  the key is that the scene gets you to think "wow, Barry really is a  total idiot!" and the whole thing will likely crumble beneath Tim,  including his job and relationship. Finally, Carell's Barry starts to  feel like a real character. Although not a cure-all for the film's  ills, that establishment works wonders on your ability to merely enjoy  it at all.  We've known for a while that Carell can do the idiot thing. From  "Anchorman" to seven seasons of "The Office" on NBC, no one does the  clueless guy better or to greater comic effect. He churns Barry into a  fairly likable numbskull, but the character operates as Michael Scott  on "The Office" and Brick Tamland from "Anchorman" combined into one  schizophrenic person. At one moment he's sweetly screwing everything  up, the next he's laughing at a chimpanzee on television. Given the  writing, it's not entirely evident just how stupid (or what kind of  stupid) Barry is supposed to be. Only toward the end does it take  shape. Director Jay Roach ("Meet the Parents," "Austin Powers") also  finds his groove here too.  "Schmucks" loosely follows the French film, the big change being the  actual dinner itself, which never happens in the original. Here, it  serves as the last-ditch effort for laughs by introducing bizarre  peripheral characters in the form of the other idiot guests, the  highlight being a woman who acts as a psychic medium for dead animals.  Some of the components of this finale are meant to serve the individual  subplots for Barry and Tim, which along with a few laughs make it  worthwhile. We learn, for example, that Barry's wife left him because,  as he puts it, "he lost the clitoris." Jokes aside, it's part of what  allows Tim to see Barry's humanity and puts a nice touch on their  relationship, which is the heart of the story and what made "Le Diner  de Cons" so terrific.  Ultimately, however, the setup does the payoff no justice and  "Schmucks" never fully washes out that first lengthy bad taste. So for  different reasons, the question of true idiocy remains unanswered -- or  simply that we're all idiots, including Hollywood.  ~Steven C

Steve Carell, Paul Rudd, Stephanie Szostak, Jemaine Clement and Bruce Greenwood star in this 2010 comedy. Rudd (Anchorman) plays Tim, an executive who pitches an idea to his boss, Fender (Greenwood). Fender decides to invite Tim to a dinner where his employees bring idiots as their guests. Carell (The 40 Year Old Virgin) plays Barry, a mild-mannered, not so bright guy Tim meets and decides to bring to the dinner. Barry complicates things for Tim at first, but Tim befriends him in the process. Barry also helps Tim work things out with his girlfriend, Julie (Szostak). Clement plays artist, Kieren who works with and has a thing for Julie. This isn't bad and Carell & Rudd are great together. I recommend this.

Review title: I wish I could exterminate this Roach-infested flick from his otherwise impressive body of work
Review_body: Director Jay Roach's roach-coach comedy "Dinner for Schmucks" is one schmuck of a movie. I had an appetite for a quirky comedia pelicula with some eccentric characters and a magnetic narrative. But instead what the Roach-coach fed us was an unpleasant, dull movie about a rising executive named Tim whose superiors force him to bring a human target to humiliate in a "hence movie title". Tim meets the leading schmuck character of the film Barry while crashing his vehicle into Barry as Tim was texting while driving. Tim is played by the charismatic Paul Rudd, and Barry is played by a spectacled nerdy-looking Steve Carell. We all know that Carell and Rudd are consummate comedic pros who have proficiently showed their diverse talent both in television and movies. But there is nothing they could have done to save this awful cinebistro flick when they were handed a profoundly disoriented and steadily queasy screenplay by David Guion and Michael Handelman; a scribe that should have been "handled" by other "men". In returning to the narrative, "why?" probably because I am schmuck enough to continue to write about this movie, Tim longs to prove to his girlfriend Julie that he could move up the ranks in the business world, so he accepts the invitation by his boss Lance Fender to this "dinner for schmucks". Julie despises the idea but Tim goes along with it anyways. Upon meeting Barry and seeing all the schmuckering qualities he possesses, Tim then decides that "he has found his schmuck" for the din din. What follows is a slapstick boringpalooza which includes a stalking female psycho, a Swiss millionaire egomaniac, an outlandish artist, and a mind-controlling obsessed accountant. Actually, the last one was not too bad due to the fact that it was portrayed by the scene-stealing Zach Galifianakis. Too bad Roach did not "hang over" more scenes to the brain controller quack Therman, but not even Zach's comical efforts could save this turd of a movie. My main complaint of the cinematic service of "Dinner for Schmucks" was the disservice it did in degrading those with eccentric hobbies or passions. Sure it had to be part of the narrative, but Roach (who has proved he is a viable talented auteur in the past) did nothing inspiring or genial to glorify those with certain "out of the ordinary" talents or as the mass bullying population likes to call them.. "idiots" or "nerds". So without a doubt, this film is major ammunition to increase the senseless bullying that hurts many day after day. Maybe I should take it as a grain of salt, and not dwell on it, but there was no tasty grain of salt or anything else tasty for that matter in this cinematic dinner table that should warrant a reservation with the "Dinner for Schmucks". ** Needs Improvement

Review title: feel free to go on a diet
Review_body: Time for a sad confession : although I've seen my share of comedies, I am unfamiliar with the French movie "Dinner for Schmucks" is based on. This is "a hole in my culture", as they say here in Flanders, but alas, it is true. On the plus side, I watched "Dinner" without preconceptions. The movie tells the story of a young and ambitious executive. Fate seems to smile upon him when his boss invites him to a dinner party. There's one catch : guests are expected to bring along weirdos and misfits, so that those who are in on the joke can have a good laugh. As it so happens, the young executive has just met a prime fool... The movie fails, mainly because it cannot decide what it wants to be : sharp, fierce and cynical or heart-warming and life-affirming. It tries to be both, resulting in an unholy tonal mess. Three other reasons why the movie sucks like a Transsylvanian count : 1) a lack of subtlety, 2) big sugary dollops of sentimentality and 3) some pretty weird ideas about what does, and what doesn't, constitute cuteness. For instance, at the beginning of "Dinner", there is a sequence where a man creates a gloriously sunny and happy little landscape, complete with miniature mice-shaped dolls. How adorable ! Little mice courting, juggling, frolicking ! It is only later that the viewer discovers that these are supposed to be dead mice preserved by taxidermy, which is considerably more sinister. Yet for some strange reason the movie insists that this is a sweet, normal, inoffensive hobby, comparable to stamp collecting. Another example : the movie ends with one of the male characters beginning a steamy affair with a beautiful and sexy woman. How nice, one might think. However, the man is a disaster-prone and tone-deaf idiot while the woman has a history of stalking and transgressing boundaries. Give this affair three weeks and it will turn into the kind of nightmare fodder where stunned sheriffs gaze into the cameras and say : "I've been in law enforcement for 24 years now and I never saw anything like it".I'm still handing out 4 stars because I liked the central conceit, about rich jerks inviting people so that they can mock them. (Which, by the way, is a betrayal of hospitality many ancient peoples would have considered sacrilegous to the extreme.) It's a good metaphor about the way the rich view their fellow men : as victims to be flattered, abused and debased.

Of all the things that continue to surprise me about the comic genius of Steve Carell (who won me over indefinitely with his signature turn in "The 40-Year Old Virgin"), the biggest is the fact that his pervasive presence in cinema has not become a source of burned-out annoyance. Unlike Jim Carrey, who held a nation captive with his rubbery contortions and crude humor, Carell can play dramatic angles as shrewdly as sharply funny punchlines. His versatility is given a workout in "Dinner for Schmucks" (ported over from a French short), wherein he plays Barry, an overly literal-minded buffoon whose hobby is stuffing dead mice and transplanting them into serenely artistic dioramas. When he steps into traffic to save a specimen one day, he is hit by Tim (Paul Rudd), a middle-management type looking to climb the executive ladder; his superiors have tasked him with bringing an "eccentric" to a dinner designed to mock those with unique or unusual talents, the "winner" providing entry to a more powerful position. Seizing upon this opportunity against the protestations of his girlfriend, Barry becomes a disastrous drag on Tim's life for 48 hours, leading to many hilarious moments (ranging from bull-in-china-shop slapstick to inspired dialog exchanges). A veteran of the ripe-to-rancid "Austin Powers" franchise, director Jay Roach and his writers do an expert job of juxtaposing humor with a genuine empathy for the central characters -- more than mere grist for the comedic mill, Carell strikes genuinely touching dramatic notes, especially when we wonder just how the titular event is going to play without feeling hypocritical and manipulative (it helps that Rudd makes a similarly capable foil to both the humor and humanity). Aside from a running time that feels long by 20 minutes, "Dinner for Schmucks" is a date worth keeping.

A predictably loud and crass American interpretation of a mini-classic from France. This film is full of comedic actors, unintentionally following the plot of the film. The film sees businessmen bring idiots to dinner, trying to one-up each other. The film itself has a bunch of comedic actors, trying to be as over-the-top as possible, in an attempt to one-up each other. These shenanigans are distracting and sometimes shameful. As Carell and Galifianakis shoot mind bullets at each other, no one is having as much fun as them. Rudd tries to play it likable, while Carell is too stupid to care about. The original had me switching allegiances between a genuinely horrible guy and a doofus. Adding the actual dinner to the film just leads to a predictable message and a painful running time. It's nice to see so many comedians from New Zealand, the UK, and America, but no one has enough to do. The original was subtle, witty, and clever. This is a loud and obnoxious ego inflation.

Review title: Rough start, but Dinner for Schmuck's fortunately gets better.
Review_body: "Sometimes I think you think I'm an idiot."There's no denying that in some ways, Dinner for Schmucks is a disappointment. There are sky high expectations (at least, from me), whenever Steve Carell and Paul Rudd team up, as they are two of the funniest actors working today. Anything the two of them collaborate on should be amazing, and sadly, Dinner for Schmucks falls short of that mark.The first of main two problems was that Carell's character (the primary schmuck referenced in the title) is so idiotic, insufferable, and unlikeable, that it throws much of the movie off. He's like a walking disaster from the second Paul Rudd's character meets him, until almost right up until the end. Imagine Carell's character from The Office, only 5 times stupider, 10 times more annoying, and with no real redeeming qualities. Towards the end of the film, there's an attempt to make the character more sympathetic and likable, but by then I was so thoroughly sick of him that it was almost too late. The second problem I had with Dinner for Schmucks is that so many of the jokes, especially in the early part of the movie, were complete and utter misses. It's like the writers were just throwing out every gag they could think of to see if any of it would stick. Fortunately, there were some really hilarious parts, as well, and a lot of them were thanks to the outstanding supporting cast. Especially Zach Galifiankis and Lucy Punch, who completely stole the movie every time they were on-screen. Eventually, Carell and Rudd got some better material to work with, too, making the last two-thirds of the movie a much funnier experience.Dinner for Schmucks started off as a pretty mediocre comedy, but it slowly picked up steam until I was reasonably pleased with it, by the end. It's no 40 Year-Old Virgin or Anchorman, but it's worth checking out.

Review title: Steve Carell Keeps the Film Entertaining
Review_body: I was not too impressed when I saw this film in theaters. I had been excited for it because I'm a major fan of it's two leads: Paul Rudd and Steve Carell. Rarely has either of these comedians been in a film that I didn't enjoy, but this one came close. The film is about Tim Conrad (Rudd) who is given the opportunity for a long-awaited promotion when he impresses his boss. As a form of initiation, Tim is invited to a special dinner where each person brings a "special" guest. The game is to see who can bring the biggest idiot and Tim believes he's found a winner when he (literally) runs into Barry Speck (Carell). Barry is an IRS agent whose hobby is making dioramas with dead mice. Meanwhile, Tim's long-time girlfriend Julie (Stephanie Szostak) is appalled at the idea of making fun of people for entertainment and their relationship is strained when Tim seems determined to attend the dinner to impress his boss and prove he's ready to move up in the company. Matters are complicated when Barry becomes involved and Tim's life begins to fall apart around him.The main problem with this film was the advertising campaign. The trailers lead viewers to believe that the dinner and it's lunatic attendees are a major portion of the film. In reality, the dinner doesn't occur until the final 20 minutes or so and the bulk of the film is watching Barry's arrival unravel Tim's life. It's not a terrible problem, but it is unfortunately misleading to those who aren't familiar with the film this movie was based upon, LE DINER DE CONS. As I watched this film originally in theaters, I was a bit let down and perhaps that affected how I received it. I've seen it since and each time I watch it, I find myself laughing more and more. It's certainly growing on me and I'm coming to appreciate the cast's performances more each time. There's definitely some quotable material here (mostly thanks to Jemaine Clement) and the film boasts some great talent.Paul Rudd has proved himself a great straight-man in recent comedies and he continues to impress here. He isn't given a lot of great moments as he's meant to be recipient of the chaos, courtesy of Carell as his idiot. I'm starting to see this as one of my favorite performances from Carell. He's a complete fool but he is so unbelievably charming that you can only laugh at him, even in his dumbest moments. He injects Barry with enough heart to keep him from becoming the creepy guy who plays with dead mice. The film's other great role would be Jemaine Clement as artist Kieran Vollard. I definitely got an Aldous Snow vibe from him, though instead of a crazed rock star he's a sexed up modern artist. He's got some of the best lines in the film ("I'm just a goat that's halfway through eating itself.") and he plays it completely deadpan. We also get the usual comedy from Zach Galifianakis as Barry's boss Therman. His character has a lot of qualities in common with his character in THE HANGOVER (idiotic with over-confidence) but he does it well and it's yet to wear thin on me.The film has a bit of a jerky pace and it feels like it runs on a bit too long, but that's all forgotten when we finally arrive at the titular dinner. The final 20 minutes of the film are the best and make the whole film worth watching, if only once. It's a funny enough flick and it's great to see Rudd and Carell working off each other. It's not going to garner any awards attention but it's good for a couple laughs if you're in the mood.

Review title: A mindless comedy and nothing more
Review_body: I've heard it been said that comedy is just non sequiturs. Clearly, that's all the writers of "Dinner for Schmucks" think about comedy as well.The movie appears to have been made for the sole purpose of laughing at one-liners and non sequiturs. And yes, I did laugh, but where was the wit, or smart humour, or multi-layered jokes? I was expecting more, but they didn't give me more. Well, let me rephrase that, I was expecting more intelligence to the comedy, but all they gave me that was extra was a romantic comedy story-line. With great leads like Steve Carell and Paul Rudd, they could have, and should have, gone more off-road.If you're just looking for a mindless comedy, then "Dinner for Schmucks" certainly fits the bill. As far as mindless comedies go, it's actually a pretty decent one. It is funny and you will laugh, a lot. I was just hoping that it was time that comedies would go further and give us more.

'Dinner for Schmucks' is a very poor remake attempt of a successful French film titled 'Le Diner de Cons'. On paper, this should have been a really funny film. With great comedy actors like Steve Carell, David Walliams and Zach Galifianakis, you would have thought this movie would have been impossible to mess up.Somehow though, despite the star-studded lineup, 'Dinner for Schmucks' manages to be virtually humourless. I gave up and switched off after an hour, having not laughed once and found the plot and characters to be extremely annoying.The film just doesn't work. Not only is it not funny, but it's also dull and boring - the last thing you expect from a comedy movie. I don't normally like giving 1 star ratings and usually reserve them for the worst of the worst, but given the total waste of a great cast on such a dreadful script, in this case I think it's justified.

Despite mixed reviews, I still had a blast with this film.Paul Rudd is Tim, your typical business man who tries to get in good with the company. By doing so, he is invited for a so called "Dinner for idiots", where they find morons, bring them there, and make fun of them. Tim hits Barry(Steve Carell), a nerdy guy who makes models with dead mice, with his car.This is obviously a mistake. Because Barry is a moron. And he ruins Tim's life. He helps his relationship with his girlfriend Julie go down, he gets Tim involved with this psycho that he slept with, and he ruins his job opportunities. Which, if you think about it, is karma for going to such a party.Dinner for Schmucks is hilarious. It keeps going until the end. The supporting cast is excellent also. Dinner for Schmucks is more adventurous than you'd want to believe. It's a very entertaining film also, and I laughed out loud numerous times.When you first hear about what its about, you'll think "That's sick". But actually, it has a good message in the end. If you do something mean to others, it will come back to bite you on the ass. It did for Tim. I'm glad it covered that. Carell and Rudd are two of the funniest people out there, and Roach has always had a talent for funny films. Together, these three make a comedy that is high on energy. See it.B+
