Despite its misleading, preposterous title, this is one of the most intellectually challenging movies of the decade. Hidden beneath a fine layer of sparkling jokes (a vast majority of the audience won't notice anything else), the subtle, Matryoshka-like construction unfolds a very unusual and surprising plot. Film director Jay Roach, best known for directing the "not-that-deep" Austin Powers films, now pursues a completely different track, which he had already foreshadowed in "Recount" (2008), and joins the league of gods among Charlie Chaplin and Woody Allen. Roach combines Jungian archetypes (not to reveal to much of the plot, just notice that Tim corresponds to the Anima) with satire and a scathing criticism on society and the American way of life. It is not for no reason that Noam Chomsky declares "Dinner for Schmucks" to be "the best romantic comedy since City Lights".

Although many reviewers gave less than perfect scores to this film, I personally found it to be so much more than I expected. Not only did it deliver the promised antics of Steve Carell and Germaine Clement but it also surprised me with a supporting cast of hilarious actors and actresses. My favorites were David Walliams of "Little Britian" fame and Chris O'Dowd of "The IT Crowd." Germaine Clement's character was probably the most engaging of all, even overshadowing Steve Carell's. If you are a fan of Clement, this is a must see. The style was zany and nonsensical in the way that many British Comedies are. Although it wasn't the greatest film ever, I certainly believe it deserves 9 out of 10 stars. It is well worth watching!

Review title: I was the crazy loud laugher in the back!
Review_body: I read the reviews on this and I couldn't believe how many people really didn't like it. But, to each their own.1. Watch "Diner des Cons" first. It is very different humor (French), slower (French), and a lot like the remake but yet the remake took off from it - so you won't get the same thing. The "con" (idiot) is (was?) an amazing French actor and his character... excruciating to watch. In fact almost the whole movie is. But it is really art (and if you study theater... uses the "Unite' des temps" which I don't know in English - takes place in 24 hours and in "one" location) and finely crafted! And you should watch this first because to watch this after: a. you won't see the nods to the original and b. it will probably be hard to watch this version after (like reading a book after).2. You truly and absolutely don't need to watch the first to "get it". Our 12 year old and 16 year old kids loved the movie (though a very few jokes were maybe a little too sexual for the 12 year... the world today). Anyway, they laughed tons. They understood the greater meaning. We quoted the movie and laughed on the way home!3. Francis Veber is one of my favorite French directors. Maybe I'm biased then to like this remake? But also, it made me very critical and standards were quite high... I was leery of what Hollywood might do to it... and ended up pleased. I laughed a lot.4. I love Steve Carrell, Zach G, Germaine, et al. Really felt they fit and played their roles very well. I really do think it was Steve to his finest! To say this is just to make fun at the people at dinner (mean spirited), don't realize the greater theme - which I think is there. That theme is present more if you see the original first. I can be one that doesn't laugh easily but they had me and many times I didn't see the joke coming - which makes a laugh out loud situation. The character "con" might be hard to watch - but not as nearly as the French version where I almost wanted to rip out my hair - but isn't that sort of good - play with the boundary of uncomfortable...?5. It IS an "Americanized" version and "expansion" of the French... so it will different. It is funny to the American sense of humor like I laughed (chuckled) to the French sense of humor in the original. (I'm span both sides). There is a blend, I think, but it couldn't be successful here if not "americanized" in humor and culture, yet keeps the nods and such to the French. I find the blend successful. Remakes are hard - but I think this one was a success in spirit and in form.6. It's not just me who loved it. The theater - one of the "loudest" comedies I've seen. I heard belly laughs, chuckles, etc.See for yourself...... I don't know if you'll like it be we sure did.

Review title: It's silly, it's stupid and it's fun
Review_body: This film shocked me. A new premise of cinema I am not familiar with, and had a very silly, very quirky style of story telling. I have to stick my neck out on this one but I enjoyed it. I like my comedies, from the classics to the obscure, and this feature manages to slot itself in there somewhere. It's not rip roaringly funny but it makes you smile, makes you giggles and still manages to create a personal attachment to the characters. When they feel bad, we feel bad. When they put themselves through awkward, cringe-worthy situations we cringe along with them and we all end up laughing at the other end.Stop trying to take this film seriously, it's not trying to be a serious film. It's about a group of idiots being shown of for being idiots by a bunch of corporate idiots. It's silly, fun and worth seeing.I found the acting was good, little ropey in places but general was to standard, the direction was well thought out, the cinematography was clever and the set design and props (especially the mice) were all manufactured so well and realistically they helped to hold the film together. This is no Godfather II but it'd no Manos: The hands of Fate either, it's a very silly, very goofy, very fun film to watch with friends, family or on your own. Everyone knows a Schmuck and everyone can relate to this film.

Personally, I am a major fan of Steve Carell, partially consisting of his performance on "the Office". If you are a fan of that series, you will surely love "Dinner for Schmucks". The humour was excellent, and the idea was great. I thought the line-up of actors was also a good choice, and fitted this movie very well. I give this a 10/10, and, it is by far, one of the funniest movies released in 2010.This movie certainly never lost it's audience; with the story constantly flipping and twisting, it kept you focused and watching. I never lost interest, nor did I ever refrain from laughter. This is probably something I could watch over and over and never get tired of. I really do not understand how it could not be liked, but for it being inappropriate for younger viewers at times. Two thumbs up for the actor playing "Therman" - he was spectacular in the hangover, playing "Allan", and has definitely shown that same humour in "Dinner for Schmucks". I highly recommend this movie, whether you need a good, hard laugh, or if you're just into the comedy scene. I loved it.

Dinner for Schmucks is the adaptation of the French movie "Le dinner de Cons" which in itself is an adaptation of the play of the same name. In the original version Pierre Brochant (Thierry L'Hermitte) is a successful editor that takes part in monthly dinners where each host has to invite "a schmuck". On the night where Pierre and his "schmuck are supposed to go to dinner Pierre hurts his back and is unable to attend the dinner, therefore the evening takes a very strange turn of events including his wife's ex-husband an I.R.S inspector and a car accident.When David Guion and Michael Handelman put there hands on this script not only did they change the whole idea of the movie they also transformed it's meaning, the original version had a deeply ironic tone in which Francois Pignon (Tim) trying to do the right thing makes everything worse whereas in this version everything finishes well.In the American remake the movie is filled with an insane artist, a crazy ex-girlfriend and a psychic nemesis. The American company responsible for this release turned into ridicule a French classic. The message of hope conveyed in the movie is feeble and not believable in any way. Overall Big Brother has come in with a big wallet and once again transformed a French masterpiece into a ridiculous feel-good American production. The only positive note is the act of both Steve Carell and Paul Rudd who despite a shaky scenario manage to pull off a great performance.To sum-up I highly recommend the original version and advise you to stay away from the American re-make.

I'm French and I have to say, I was very excited when I found out Le Dîner de Cons was going to have a remake, and I thought it could be ok, since the American remake of LOL was pretty good. I was mainly enticed by the idea of Paul Rudd playing the normal dude and Steve Carell playing the idiot. I thought it would be a brilliant cast.So I watched a few years ago and I hated it. So much so that I had given it a 1 on here to balance out the good critics. But after seeing the Anchorman movies and enjoying Brick's character, I thought I should give this a second chance without thinking of it as a remake.It simply didn't make me laugh. It was way too over the top, Steve Carell's character is too dumb, and in Anchorman it works because everybody's dumb. Here the two main characters don't fit together at all, and the writing is just not funny enough. It is a waste of a very good concept and two wonderful comedic actors.The reason I give it 4 stars now (and I think I am being nice):
1 star for Paul Rudd whose character was ok (although it could be so much more)1 star for the French actress who hints that the original is French (although a cameo of one of the actors in original movie would have been even better, yes I know Jacques Villeret is long gone, but any of the living ones)1 star for the fact that they actually went to dinner, which is something I always wished to see more of in the original, but again a waste of a good idea1 star for the moral of the story which is clearer here than in the original, aka don't be mean to people even if you think they are idiots. They still should have included the phrase 'we are all someone else's idiot'

Dinner for Schmucks is one of the funniest movies I have seen in a long time. I love comedies, but very few make me laugh out loud - but this movie had me bursting out every couple of minutes. I was not alone in that, the theater I saw it in was packed and everyone was in hysterics. Some reviews on here actually complain that it is "low brow" or "stupid" - seriously? Where you expecting a deep and insightful movie? Had you seen the previews? Is it realistic? Of course not (not many movies are - it is called suspension of disbelief). The point of a comedy is to make you laugh. Going in with expectations of anything high brow is absurd. If you like The Office or 40 Year Old Virgin, then you will love this movie - it is in a similar vein, but much cleaner than 40 Year Old Virgin. In fact, it is surprisingly funny for a PG-13 film. Can't understand any of the bad reviews - if you like Steve Carell, Paul Rudd and Jay Roach movies - then this is for you - one of the funniest projects any of them has been involved in.
